North Korea Opens 1st Fast-Food Restaurant: Report
KWANG-TAE KIM 07/25/09 10:22 PM ET Associated Press React Important Fascinating Typical Scary Outrageous Amazing Infuriating Beautiful Follow Fast Food , North Korea , Fast Food Korea , Hamburger , Minced Beef And Bread , Pyongyang , World News share this story Get World Alerts Sign Up Submit this story digg reddit stumble SEOUL, South Korea—You still can't get a hamburger in Pyongyang, but the suspiciously similar "minced beef and bread" is for sale at the North Korean capital's first fast-food restaurant, a news report said Saturday.
The Samtaesong restaurant opened in the isolated communist country last month in cooperation with a Singaporean company, according to the Tokyo-based Choson Sinbo. The Singaporean company, which the newspaper did not name, provided training to restaurant staff and supplied equipment.
The restaurant's interior appears to be styled after fast-food joints the world over, but the menu is careful not to call its signature fare a hamburger–lest it give the impression North Koreans had embraced the American icon.
North Korea's authoritarian government is concerned that outside influences could undermine the regime and pose a threat to leader Kim Jong Il's tight grip on the nation of 24 million. It balks at using foreign words and coins alternatives in Korean instead.
But this is not the government's first foray into foreign food. In March, the Choson Sinbo, widely considered a mouthpiece for the North Korean government, reported that Kim–a noted gourmand–had ordered the opening of the country's first Italian restaurant. The chefs there were trained in Italy and food made with imported ingredients was served.
The restaurants are unlikely to be frequented by ordinary people in North Korea, which is one of the world's poorest countries and experiences chronic food shortages.
The minced beef and bread at the new fast-food restaurant costs only $1.70, the newspaper said, but that would eat up more than half of the average North Korean's daily income. South Korea's central bank put last year's average per capita income at $1,065.
The restaurant also offers kimchi–Korean pickled cabbage–as well as waffles and draft beer. It plans to add croissants and hot dogs to its menu in the coming months but with Korean names, and will open another branch in the capital soon, according to the newspaper. Loading comments… Antonio518 45 Fans 02:44 PM on 07/26/2009 Cuba has a fast food chain (El Rapido) For a dollar you can get a hamburger, a tropicola and fries, or a half chicken, tropicola and fries. Cubans make movie that are shown all over the world. Cubans trade with other countries, and have spanking new hotels and shopping centers, where Cubans can stay and shop if they have the money. . At Jose Marti airport in La Habana you can see Cubans leaving and coming back in droves. The planes are full of tourists, but also full of Cubans who have passports and business of holidays to take care of. I don't know about Korea, but I suspect that it is more successful and more vital than we are led to believe. Loading comments… Maanu 14 Fans 02:07 PM on 07/26/2009 It's so easy to beat up on North Korea and the lack of freedoms there, and how Kim Jong is ill. America, take a good look in the mirror. Give it a couple generations of forgotten gains, and we are a hair's breadth away from where they are today. They have stunted growth, we have the freedom to get fat, come down with diabetes, and be charged exorbitantly to have it treated. Who has killed more people outside of their country, the US or Nor Kor? Not even close. They've got nukes, they're scary. Guess what, we've actually used them. Perhaps the reason we can laugh about North Korea is not because they seem crazy, but because their lunacy is backwoods compared to our sophisticated genocide. They've got propaganda for sure, but when's the last time you've seen a North Korean blockbuster film? It's called the lesser of two evils.
